thread.title: Yani Tseng tied for third at Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia
thread.title_full: Yani Tseng tied for third at Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia

title: Yani Tseng tied for third at Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia
text:
Yani Tseng tied for third at Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia CNAOctober 10, 2015, 12:01 am TWN SHARE Tweet TAIPEI -- Taiwanese golfer Yani Tseng (曾雅妮) recovered from a terrible start in the second round of the Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur on Friday to shoot a 3-under 68 and end the day tied for third in the US$2 million tournament. 
Tseng was tied with Inbee Park of South Korea and Alison Lee of the United States at 8-under 134, two shots behind the leader Ha Na Jang of South Korea and one behind Lin Xiyu of China. 
On a day full of low scores Friday, the former world No. 1 bogeyed two of her first three holes, when by her own account her tempo was a little off, but recovered with birdies on the sixth, eighth and 12th holes to get back in the hunt before bogeying the par-4 14th. 
She then birdied three of her last four holes, however, to catapult herself back up to near the top of the leaderboard, and she hopes to keep the momentum going on the weekend. 
"Everything is good. Putting is getting better, and then I finish with birdie (on three) out of like the last four holes. So it's always a good sign to make lots of birdies out there," she said. 
Tseng had six birdies and one bogey to card a 66 in the first round Thursday. 
Tseng, whose last victory came in March 2012, came excruciatingly close a month and half ago when she finished as the runner-up at the Yokohama Tire LPGA Classic, and being in contention again seems to suit her. 
"Just feel very comfortable," Tseng said. "Just very happy to be back in position, see my name on the first page of the leaderboard." 
Another Taiwanese player, Candie Kung (龔怡萍), was tied for 14th at 5-under 137 after a second-round 3-under 68, and Hsu Wei-ling (徐微凌) was tied for the 37th at 1-under 141 after a 3-under 68 on Friday that was marred only by a bogey on the final hole. 
Lee Min was tied for 61st in the 75-player field at 4-over. SHARE
